comment.author: 8458735@N05
comment._content: I would guess the kid isn't a slave.  Rather, he would be a gun bearer.  Gun bearers carried firearms for the hunters while hunting, and would often act as trackers (or most likely backup trackers).  They were paid for their services, and often earned a good living in relation to others in the area.

comment.author: 44001546@N00
comment._content: Oh - and as regards the status of the little boy - as the photo was taken in London he had probably never seen Africa and probably spoke with a cockney accent.

comment.author: 7576993@N07
comment._content: Thank you all for commenting on our photo! The boy with Stanley is Kalulu ( d. 1877), identified in literature as Stanley's servant, page, and sometimes adopted child. Although Stanley did bring him back to England with him and educated him, it is doubtful that Kalulu spoke with a cockney accent : )

comment.author: 21942512@N00
94495740@N00
comment._content: Kalulu is educated in England and still being used to pose for this staged photo? Yes, it does tell some tale.

comment.author: 24432542@N04
comment._content: Wow.

comment.author: 60026579@N00
comment._content:
Alishaan, I don't think anyone here would argue that the boy owned the gun (or anything else, for that matter).  Rather, as a servant, one of his duties was that as a gun bearer, as mentioned in a previous comment.  While both guns shown are being used as props for this staged photo, the young man probably carried that very gun and others many miles over his life for Mr. Stanley and others.
Historically, it was quite common for a white man to teach a young servant like this to shoot as well.  In this photo, both of these guns are likely either single or double barreled rifles.  Repeating rifles of large enough caliber to kill dangerous African game ranging from lions to elephants simply did not exist at this time.
Therefore, having a servant (or a few) who knew how to shoot could come in quite handy in life-threatening encounters with wild game.
I agree with your assessment of the treatment of Africans by whites, but will point out that it is a fact that young men like this were often trusted with loaded weapons, just as some African slaves in America (also most often young boys) were trusted to perform similar duties for Southern plantation owners, toting their shotguns and extra ammunition during quail hunts.

p.s. Foreignobesessed, I can't, for the life of me, grasp whether or not your comment is supposed to be sarcastic, racist, or what.  Having a servant carry an elephant gun has nothing to do with modern people of any race currently having weapons.

comment.author: 36859674@N04
comment._content: I don't think it is racist.  The black person HAS A GUN.  And this photo was taken after the Emancipation Proclamation; the boy is not his slave.

comment.author: 8458735@N05
comment._content: Alishaann - no doubt the treatment of the natives by the colonials was horrible, I only wanted to point out the history behind the use of gun-bearers on hunts.

comment.author: 60026579@N00
comment._content:
Foreignobsessed,  Thank you for the reply via a comment here.  From what I have read, the egos of these European "great white hunters" likely didn't lead to them using servants to kill dangerous game.  However, I would bet that on more than one occasion, a servant probably saved the life of Stanley and those like him.  They likely were also dispatched to hunt small game for table fare for the white men.

An interesting read is "The Last Ivory Hunter" by Peter Hathaway Capstick.  While his behavior might be perceived today as racist by some, he didn't see it that way.  He writes "...They weren't lesser people, of course--just different from their white fellow countrymen when it came to way of life and values.  Much in the way that a Japanese businessman differs from a Finn in how he views the world and what he considers important".

In this book, which can be found in it's entirety on Google, the author also speaks of the salary which he paid his head gun-bearer, who left after being given a raise after 20 years of employment.  The "bush logic" this man used told him that if he received a raise, it must have mean that he had been worth the greater amount for his previous years of employment, and he was upset that he had not been paid his full worth from day one.

comment.author: 73172111@N00
comment._content:
Wonderful picture! Staged photos like this in the late 1800s were used to illustrate news stories and distant cultures because technology did not allow for on the spot authentic recording of visual images. While artists could depict events with pen and carvings, photography was an irresistable new instrument for journalists seeing the possibility of authenticity instead of artistic interpretation. The transition was awkward, as seen here.

This is one of the baby steps on the way to modern photojournalism. 

I find some of the comments here ridiculously out of context for the time and events and locale represented. We cannot judge the quality of this photo in terms of today's technology, nor should we judge the race relations among peoples who had just discovered each other in terms of today's environment where we grow up together as neighbors, and even as family members. It didn't take long for humanity to reach this point, considering the thousands of years of war, conquest and slavery prior to the days of this photo. 

We owe the turning point that changed all of our lives to men like Livingstone and Stanley. L's life and S's writings brought empathy and compassion into the picture, replacing hatred, exploitation and dehumanizing beliefs. These were important baby steps that we must understand and appreciate for their historical significance - not ridicule and judge harshly from today's perspective.

I find humor in this picture, even if it wasn't intentional. I think of the progress of both photojournalism and race relations in the short few generations between then and now. Do you see how there can be a connection?

comment.author: 24474353@N06
comment._content:
One thing is for certain... the amount of energy given this photo in regard to racism says a lot about people today.  It seems that any avenue available to vent about even the remote hint of impropriety between the races is not acceptable and fair game, even if the subject matter comes from over a hundred years ago!  I am sure the reaction for this photo ten years from now will be different than what we are experiencing now. Let's look at it as a good thing .. where ten years ago, probably nobody would have said anything.  Personally i took it at face value: famous hunter/explorer ... a historical figure and a rare photo.. however now i have been forced to see beyond the setting and examine the time and tide and new feeling come up with the hope that the negative aspects of life in those days may somehow never be relived.. however some would say that even greater atrocities than racism exist and are perpetrated in the world today..  see. .. The Middle East, Africa, South America, Mexico, Afghanistan, Indonesia, Phiippines, .. North Korea.. etc etc.  
On a more humorous note some would say that my profile pic give me a neanderhalic look.  ..  good luck and good bye.
Ray

comment.author: 51021482@N04
comment._content:
Maravilhosa imagem! Encenado fotos como esta no final de 1800 foram utilizados para ilustrar as notícias e culturas distantes, porque a tecnologia não permitia a gravação no local autêntico de imagens visuais. Enquanto os artistas podiam retratar eventos com caneta e esculturas, a fotografia era um instrumento irresistível novo para os jornalistas a possibilidade de ver a autenticidade ao invés de interpretação artística. A transição foi difícil, como pode ser visto aqui. 

Esta é uma das etapas do bebê a caminho de fotojornalismo moderno. 

Acho que alguns dos comentários aqui absurdamente fora do contexto do tempo e dos acontecimentos e localidade representada. Não podemos julgar a qualidade dessa foto em termos de tecnologia de hoje, nem devemos julgar as relações raciais entre os povos que tinham acabado de descobrir um ao outro em termos de ambiente de hoje, onde nós crescemos juntos como vizinhos, e até mesmo como membros da família. Não demorou muito para a humanidade chegar a este ponto, considerando a milhares de anos de guerra, conquista e escravidão antes do dia desta foto. 

Devemos o ponto de viragem que mudou nossas vidas para homens como Livingstone e Stanley. L's da vida e os escritos S trouxe empatia e compaixão na imagem, substituindo o ódio, a exploração e desumanização crenças. Estes foram passos de bebê importante que devemos entender e apreciar a sua importância histórica - não ridicularizar e julgar duramente a partir da perspectiva de hoje. 

Acho que o humor neste retrato, ainda que não foi intencional. Eu acho que os progressos de ambos fotojornalismo e as relações raciais no curto poucas gerações entre aquela época e agora. Você vê como pode haver uma conexão?

comment.author: 29202481@N03
comment._content: I am glad this photo has generated so much historical speculation. I think most folks these days realize that our history is distorted, and much of it never told. And who gets to tell the story? Why, the ones who were the oppressors, and exploiters or course. And many of theier descendants are still in charge, and still hold the key to the storytelling door; this is, until the internet. Perhaps Stanley was "nice" to his slave-servant boy. We will never know. What is certain is this; those who "owned" or controlled slaves and servants used them liberally for work, sex, and entertainment. Romantic photos of the Good Old Days are really just lies about the past, children posed for scenes that were never really real.

comment.author: 39265083@N05
comment._content: A modern person's first impression of the photo would likely be that it was racist. However, there is nothing in the white man's pose that indicates his assertion of his supremacy over the boy. They could have been 2 white men standing (or a white man and a white boy), each minding his own pose as the photograph was being taken. Had the man or the photographer been more sensitive to modern day sensibilities, they might have put more clothes on the boy, and perhaps made the man kneel down on one knee (or sit) so he wouldn't appear that much taller.  But would he have done the same then had the boy been white and just as much a stranger?

comment.author: 29202481@N03
comment._content: There is a story behind this story, and it is not pretty; if you do some research, you liable to find out some not-so-nice things. To the contrary of what anyone may say, Colonialism was, and is, wrong. These posed pictures are interesting, but one must read behind the lines or one will have a truly false notion of history (through rosy lenses).

comment.author: 39265083@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/tropicalgardener] I have no doubt there were more than just a few atrocities commited by colonizers upon the colonized back in the day. I was just commenting about the impression the photo was likely to make upon the viewer.  Given what you've said, perhaps it would even be more commendable of the journalist to have been disinclined to pose in a way as to assert his superiority over the native boy.  

About colonialism being morally wrong, I'd beg to differ.  It would be as if you said that education was not a good thing to have happened to the savage peoples of old.  Exploitation, however, now that's something different, and I'm not saying it never happened in the process.

comment.author: 29202481@N03
comment._content: CoconutPilot, Colonialism is always a tremendous economic benefit to the invader, and sometimes to the invaded. However, to stay in a place where you are not welcome is not right, and, historically, cannot last long. For instance, we are no longer welcome in Iraq or most of the Middle East; and everyone knows we are just hanging around for the oil. For the English, it was the slaves, ivory and gold. In this day and age, to defend colonialism is a bit backward looking, and false history. If you ask an Englishman if he thinks colonialism was good, you are bound to get a mixed answer. If you ask a native of a colonized country that was invaded and oppressed by the English, you are bound to get another answer. Naturally, history's reality depends upon perspective. One person's terrorist is another person's freedom fighter. Little black boys and grown white men do not belong with one another in any intimate setting, though they sure seem to have in the past. Finally, there were plenty of whites who thought colonialism was wrong during the past, yet there voices were few or suppressed. The point? Claiming it is hard to pass judgement on those in the past from our time vantage point  is simple not true; many educated people knew slavery and colonialism were evil prongs of the same snakes tongue. Final point; those who defend colonialism are often descended from the old oppressors and, therefore, benefitted (some greatly) from that oppression and must justify the historical oppression in order to justify their current existence. At least the ones who care about history, justice and morals.

comment.author: 39265083@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/tropicalgardener] Correct me if I'm wrong but I don't believe I took anyone's perspective in this. To me, the human subjects in the photo are mere representations of  people coming from 2 very different cultures. I don't see any reason for me to perceive it as something more than that. On the other hand, a person who is overly sensitive to whatever implications a picture may project, might be hasty to judge it as racist. Nevertheless, as I've pointed out in my previous post, there really was no reason in the photo for one to make such a valid conclusion--and that was all I was really trying to say.

About your comment that "little black boys and grown white men don't belong together in an intimate setting" might have been a bit simplified, as I'm sure you won't have a problem seeing a picture of a grown white expeditionist posing with, say, an Inca boy.  It sounded like you were saying that racial tension existed merely between the white and the black race, but I'm quite certain that is not the case.

As I've said before, I am sure there were a lot of cases of racist abuse commited by colonizers back in the era of colonization. Nevertheless, even the most "unfair" of colonists had a great deal of good to contribute to the colonized peoples as a whole, such that they eventually were better off for it. Take South America for instance.  I'm sure you would agree that whatever injustices the Spaniards may have done to the natives in the time that followed, they were still far better off than they were before the arrival of the conquistadors.

comment.author: 29202481@N03
comment._content:
CoconutPilot: I appreciate your best try, but your thinking it old, tired, and, thank goodness, dying out; young, educated people don't cling to these myths anymore.

Truly: I no longer wish to participate in this discussion. Thanks :)

comment.author: 39265083@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tropicalgardener] Fine, but if i may, would you rather the savage world remain in their savagery than utilize your superior military might to introduce them to a better way of life? Or if you would rather be "civil" would you really be willing to risk your life trying to educate belligerent barbarians like a Christian missionary would?  All I'm saying is the benefit far outweighed the negative consequences of the expansionist endeavors of the colonists.

comment.author: 27817825@N07
comment._content: Well CoconutPilot1, what about the native North and South Americans? They were savages after all and we came for God and to get rich south of the equator; where there is no sin by the way.

comment.author: 39265083@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27817825@N07] Well, I wasn't saying the colonizers had nothing but pure motives.  I was just opposed to the idea that colonialism offered no benefit to the natives at all, which I believe Tropicalgarderner was saying when he asserted that colonialism was all wrong.  Nevertheless, all I was really commenting about was how people would tend to put unjustifiable meaning to this particular picture, which ironically is prejudice in itself.

comment._content: The past is even worse than what the false history teller (publisher of old books, old lies); many of these nice white men were molesting, raping and murdering children as they went deep into the heart of Africa. The WASPS hold these myths close so the seething evil will not seep out onto the pages of real history, but some of the truth will get out, and the internet will help with this. The old, romantic pictures only tell one side of the story, the side were have heard, over and over, until we are sick to the soul. We no longer believe the lies. These men were no heros, no saviors; they were exploiters, land stealers, slavers,  liars, murderers and rapists

comment.author: 75693709@N06
comment._content: great

comment.author: 24474353@N06
comment._content: Americans are not world travelers for the most part.. how many people do you know that even own a passport?  There are heinous aspects to all societies.  Slavery exists in all parts of the world in some form or another.  It may not be as prevalent today as it once was. However it flourishes in many forms from endentured servitude to sexual crimes against kidnapped victims.  Children are quite often the victims.  I believe that Stanley found himself in places and times where it was only the character and conscience of his guides and servants that allowed him to survive.  I believe he understood the efforts and sacrifices his hired men made for him to complete his adventures.  History is filled with outrageous stories of the goings on during explorations and discovery missions.  Sir Francis Drake had to deal with mutiny and the hardships of leading a group of men on a wooden vessel around a little known world.  He hung some of his men from the yard arm to keep his ship afloat.  A story is told of a navy ship from El Salvador coming to port in Hawaii in 2001 and one of the crew was caught stealing a cd from the US Navy base store.. the Salvadorans asked for permission to hang the sailor in port.  Permission denied.  The ship left port for two days.. then came back.  I am sure they came back without the sailor.  Did that make it to the media and news? i don't think so.. point is: Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men?

comment.author: 24474353@N06
comment._content: Jgury... love the photos of the child growing up and wearing a tailored suit. .. there is no doubt that is the same child. thanks for your efforts.

comment.author: 24474353@N06
comment._content:
My daughter asked me once.."Daddy when will there be world peace?" I said "when man learns not kill things in order to survive."  
Cannibals exist in this world..the Amazon.. New Guinea.. etc. Dahmer proved that cannibals can exist in the modern world.  With all of our technology, buildings, roads, cars, society.. we fail.  Evil persists as any police blotter or media headline will show you. Wholesale slaughter happens at various times and places around the world. But what we are endeavoring to do is to create peaceful places to live and raise our children.  I was in a group of American men recently and i asked how many had ever been actual witnesses to or involved in a violent fight or crime?  It came out to less than 10%.  Yeah we see it on tv or boxing events, etc.  But its rare in the USA for the most part. That is how life has changed over the last hundred years.  That is what we are striving for. The third world is a different place, but unless you are well traveled you really don't know or understand that.. and you may not really be able to appreciate what we have here.

comment.author: 67639186@N03
comment._content: Wonderful snapshot in time. May I suggest, for all those who added comments about this photograph, that Tim Jeal's book Stanley, The Impossible Life of Africa's Greatest Explorer, is extremely enlightening, surprising and utterly riveting. Published by Faber & Faber London 2007. Sunday Times Biography of the Year 2007.
